texts.html: Some comments on Noiselets

computed.font-family: 'Helvetica Neue', Arial, Helvetica, 'Nimbus Sans L', sans-serif

texts.html: Posted on August 21, 2010 by jackdurden

computed.font-family: 'Helvetica Neue', Arial, Helvetica, 'Nimbus Sans L', sans-serif

texts.html: by jackdurden

Recently, a friend of mine asked me few questions about Noiselets for Compressed Sensing applications, i.e., in order to create efficient sensing matrices incoherent with signal which are sparse in the Haar/Daubechies wavelet basis. It seems that some of the answers are difficult to find on the web (but I’m sure they are well known to specialists) and I have therefore decided to share the ones I got.
text: Recently, a friend of mine asked me few questions about

for Compressed Sensing applications, i.e., in order to create efficient sensing matrices incoherent with signal which are sparse in the Haar/Daubechies wavelet basis. It seems that some of the answers are difficult to find on the web (but I’m sure they are well known to specialists) and I have therefore decided to share the ones I got.

texts.html: Context:

I wrote in 2008 a tiny Matlab toolbox (see here) to convince myself that the Noiselet followed a Cooley-Tukey implementation already followed by the Walsh-Hadamard transform. It should have been optimized in C but I lacked of time to write this.Since this first code, I realized that Justin Romberg wrote already in 2006 with Peter Stobbe a fast code (also O(N log N) but much faster than mine) available here:
text: I wrote in 2008 a tiny Matlab toolbox (see

) to convince myself that the Noiselet followed a Cooley-Tukey implementation already followed by the Walsh-Hadamard transform. It should have been optimized in C but I lacked of time to write this.Since this first code, I realized that
wrote already in 2006 with Peter Stobbe a fast code (also O(N log N) but much faster than mine) available here:

texts.html: http://users.ece.gatech.edu/~justin/spmag

People could be interested in using Justin’s code since, as it will be clarified from my answers given below, it is already adapted to real valued signals, i.e., it produces real valued noiselets coefficients.
text: People could be interested in using Justin’s code since, as it will be clarified from my answers given below, it is already adapted to real valued signals, i.e., it produces real valued noiselets coefficients.

texts.html: Q1. Do we need to use both the real and imaginary parts of noiselets to design sensing matrices (i.e., building the matrix)?  Can we use just the real part or just the imaginary part)?  Any reason why you’d do one thing or another?
text: Q1. Do we need to use both the real and imaginary parts of noiselets to design sensing matrices (i.e., building the
matrix)?  Can we use just the real part or just the imaginary part)?  Any reason why you’d do one thing or another?

texts.html: As for the the Random Fourier Ensemble sensing, what I personally do when I use noiselet sensing is to pick uniformly at random complex values in half the noiselet-frequency domain, and concatenate the real and the imaginary part into a real vector of length . The adjoint (transposed) operation — often needed in most of Compressed Sensing solvers — must of course sum the previously split real and imaginary parts into complex values before to pad the complementary measured domain with zeros and run the inverse noiselet transform.
text: sensing, what I personally do when I use noiselet sensing is to pick uniformly at random
complex values in half the noiselet-frequency domain, and concatenate the real and the imaginary part into a real vector of length
. The adjoint (transposed) operation — often needed in most of Compressed Sensing solvers — must of course sum the previously split real and imaginary parts into
complex values before to pad the complementary measured domain with zeros and run the inverse noiselet transform.

texts.html: To understand the special treatment of the real and the imaginary parts (and not simply by considering it similar to what is done for Random Fourier Ensemble), let us consider the origin, that is, Coifman et al. Noiselets paper.
text: To understand the special treatment of the real and the imaginary parts (and not simply by considering it similar to what is done for Random Fourier Ensemble), let us consider the origin, that is,

texts.html: Recall that in this paper, two kinds of noiselets are defined. The first basis, the common Noiselets basis on the interval , is defined thanks to the recursive formulas:

, is defined thanks to the recursive formulas:

texts.html: The second basis, or Dragon Noiselets, is slightly different. Its elements are symmetric under the change of coordinates . Their recursive definition is

(2) (and also Eq (4) for Dragon Noiselets), which connects the noiselet functions between the noiselet index and indices or , is simply a common butterfly diagram that sustains the Cooley-Tukey implementation of the Noiselet transform.

texts.html: The coefficients involved in Eqs (2) and (4) are simply , which are of course complex conjugate of each other.

, which are of course complex conjugate of each other.

texts.html: Therefore, in the Noiselet transform of a real vector of length (in one to one correspondance with the piecewise constant functions of ) involving the noiselets of indices , the resulting decomposition diagram is fully symmetric (with a complex conjugation) under a flip of indices , for .

,

with the complex conjugation, if is real, and allows us to define “Real Random Noiselet Ensemble” by picking uniformly at random complex values in the half domain , that is independent real values in total, as obtained by concatenating the real and the imaginary parts (see above).

independent real values in total, as obtained by concatenating the real and the imaginary parts (see above).

texts.html: Therefore, for real valued signals, as for Fourier, the two halves of the noiselet spectrum are not independent, and therefore, only one half is necessary to perform useful CS measurements.
text: Therefore, for real valued signals, as for Fourier, the two halves of the noiselet spectrum are not independent, and therefore, only one half is necessary to perform useful CS measurements.

texts.html: Justin’s code is close to this interpretation by using a real valued version of the symmetric Dragon Noiselets described in the initial Coifman et al. paper.
text: Justin’s code is close to this interpretation by using a real valued version of the symmetric Dragon Noiselets described in the initial Coifman et al. paper.

texts.html: Q2. Are noiselets always binary?  or do they take +1, -1, 0 values like Haar wavelets?
text: Q2. Are noiselets always binary?  or do they take +1, -1, 0 values like Haar wavelets?

texts.html: Actually, a noiselet of index take the complex values , never .This can be easily seen from the recursive formula of Eq. (2).
text: .This can be easily seen from the recursive formula of Eq. (2).

texts.html: They fill also the whole interval .
text: They fill also the whole interval

texts.html:
Update — 26/8/2013:
I was obviously wrong above on the values that noiselets can take (Thank you to Kamlesh Pawar for the detection).
text: I was obviously wrong above on the values that noiselets can take (Thank you to Kamlesh Pawar for the detection).

texts.html: Noiselet amplitude can never be zero, however, either the real part or the imaginary part (not both) can vanish for certain .
text: Noiselet amplitude can never be zero, however, either the real part or the imaginary part (not both) can vanish for certain

texts.html: So, to be correct and from few computations, a noiselet of index with takes, over the interval , the complex values if is odd, and or if is even.
text: So, to be correct and from few computations, a noiselet of index

texts.html: In particular, we see that the amplitude of these noiselets is always for the considered indexes.
text: In particular, we see that the amplitude of these noiselets is always

texts.html: Q3. Walsh functions have the property that they are binary and zero mean, so that one half of the values are 1 and the other half are -1.  Is it the same case with the real and/or imag parts of the noiselet transform?
text: Q3. Walsh functions have the property that they are binary and zero mean, so that one half of the values are 1 and the other half are -1.  Is it the same case with the real and/or imag parts of the noiselet transform?

texts.html: To be correct, Walsh-Hadamard functions have mean equal to 1 if their index is a power of 2 and 0 else, starting with the [0,1] indicator function of index 1.
text: To be correct, Walsh-Hadamard functions have mean equal to 1 if their index is a power of 2 and 0 else, starting with the [0,1] indicator function of index 1.

texts.html: For Noiselets, they are all of unit average, meaning that the imaginary part has the zero average property. This can be proved easily (by induction) from their recursive definition in Coifman et al. paper (Eqts (2) and (4)). Interestingly, their unit average, that is their projection on the unit constant function, shows directly that a constant function is not sparse at all in the noiselet basis since its “noiselet spectrum” is just flat.
text: For Noiselets, they are all of unit average, meaning that the imaginary part has the zero average property. This can be proved easily (by induction) from their recursive definition in Coifman et al. paper (Eqts (2) and (4)). Interestingly, their unit average, that is their projection on the unit constant function, shows directly that a constant function is not sparse at all in the noiselet basis since its “noiselet spectrum” is just flat.

texts.html: In fact, it is explained in Coifman paper that any Haar-Walsh wavelet packets, that is, elementary functions of formula
text: In fact, it is explained in Coifman paper that any Haar-Walsh wavelet packets, that is, elementary functions of formula

texts.html: with the Walsh functions (including the Haar functions), have a flat noiselet spectrum (all coefficients of unit amplitude), leading to the well known good (in)coherence results (that is, low coherence). To recall, the coherence is given by for the Haar wvaelet basis, and it corresponds to slightly higher values for the Daubechies wavelets D4 and D8 respectively (see, e.g., E.J. Candès and M.B. Wakin, “An introduction to compressive sampling”, IEEE Sig. Proc. Mag., 25(2):21–30, 2008.)

texts.html: Q4. How come noiselets require O(N logN) computations rather than O(N) like the haar transform?
text: Q4. How come noiselets require O(N logN) computations rather than O(N) like the haar transform?

texts.html: This is a verrry common confusion. The difference comes from the locality of the Haar basis elements.
text: This is a verrry common confusion. The difference comes from the locality of the Haar basis elements.

texts.html: For the Haar transform, you can use the well known pyramidal algorithm running in computations. You start from the approximation coefficients computed at the finest scale, using then the wavelet scaling relations to compute the detail and approximation coefficients at the second scale, and so on. Because of the sub-sampling occuring at each scale, the complexity is proportional to the number of coefficients, that is, it is .
text: For the Haar transform, you can use the well known pyramidal algorithm running in

computations. You start from the approximation coefficients computed at the finest scale, using then the wavelet scaling relations to compute the detail and approximation coefficients at the second scale, and so on. Because of the sub-sampling occuring at each scale, the complexity is proportional to the number of coefficients, that is, it is

texts.html: For the 3 bases Hadamard-Walsh, Noiselets and Fourier, their non-locality (i.e., their support is the whole segment [0, 1]) you cannot run a similar alorithm. However, you can use the Cooley-Tukey algorithm arising from the Butterfly diagrams linked to the corresponding recursive definitions (Eqs (2) and (4) above).
text: For the 3 bases Hadamard-Walsh, Noiselets and Fourier, their non-locality (i.e., their support is the whole segment [0, 1]) you cannot run a similar alorithm. However, you can use the Cooley-Tukey algorithm arising from the Butterfly diagrams linked to the corresponding recursive definitions (Eqs (2) and (4) above).

texts.html: This one is in , since the final diagram has levels, each involving multiplication-additions.
Feel free to comment this post and ask other questions. It will provide perhaps eventually a general Noiselet FAQ/HOWTO

texts.html: 9 Responses to Some comments on Noiselets
Gabriel Peyré says:

computed.font-family: 'Helvetica Neue', Arial, Helvetica, 'Nimbus Sans L', sans-serif

texts.html: August 22, 2010 at 11:50 pm
In my CS experiments, I use a doubly scrambled Hadamard transform, which means,
text: In my CS experiments, I use a doubly scrambled Hadamard transform, which means,

texts.html:
y = x(randperm(n));
y = hadamard(y)); % N*log(N) operations, you can use dct or any flat ortho basis
y = y(randperm(n));
y = y(1:p); % select only p random coefficients
text: y = hadamard(y)); % N*log(N) operations, you can use dct or any flat ortho basis
y = y(1:p); % select only p random coefficients

texts.html: What is the advantage of Noiselets over this scheme ? I suspect they work similarely on data sparse in wavelets.
text: What is the advantage of Noiselets over this scheme ? I suspect they work similarely on data sparse in wavelets.

computed.font-family: 'Helvetica Neue', Arial, Helvetica, 'Nimbus Sans L', sans-serif

texts.html: Reply
jackdurden says:

computed.font-family: 'Helvetica Neue', Arial, Helvetica, 'Nimbus Sans L', sans-serif

texts.html: August 23, 2010 at 2:24 pm

Good to know. This scheme is possibly very efficient too. And another variant would be to use a spreadspectrum (i.e. pointwise multiplication by Bernoulli vector before hadamard/noiselet/fourier) instead of the first randperm.
text: Good to know. This scheme is possibly very efficient too. And another variant would be to use a spreadspectrum (i.e. pointwise multiplication by Bernoulli vector before hadamard/noiselet/fourier) instead of the first randperm.

texts.html: However, the question is how to prove that Hadamard functions + randperms provides a flat spectrum for function sparse in the Haar basis. Perhaps this can be proved, but I never read such a proof up to now. For noiselets, the proof is in Coifman et al. Noiselets paper.
text: However, the question is how to prove that Hadamard functions + randperms provides a flat spectrum for function sparse in the Haar basis. Perhaps this can be proved, but I never read such a proof up to now. For noiselets, the proof is in Coifman et al. Noiselets paper.

Regarding theory I agree that one should use noiselets. It should be doable to do the math for randomization (or spreadspectrum) and then partial hadamard.
text: Regarding theory I agree that one should use noiselets. It should be doable to do the math for randomization (or spreadspectrum) and then partial hadamard.

texts.html: August 14, 2012 at 6:48 pm
Hi there!

I am a newbie to noiselets, but will try to use them in my master thesis. My question is about real values noiselets (Q1).
I have the following data vector: [4 2 5 5]
The fnt1d (from Laurent Jacques) of this vector is:
[3.5000 - 0.5000i ; 4.5000 + 1.5000i ; 4.5000 - 1.5000i ;
3.5000 + 0.5000i]
text: I am a newbie to noiselets, but will try to use them in my master thesis. My question is about real values noiselets (Q1).
I have the following data vector: [4 2 5 5]
The fnt1d (from Laurent Jacques) of this vector is:

texts.html:
Now according to the answer to Q1, if I want the real fnt of [4 2 5 5], I take the first two imaginary entries from the fnt1d, and concatenate the real and imaginary coefficients to a vector.
Something like: [3.5 4.5 -0.5 1.5]
text: Now according to the answer to Q1, if I want the real fnt of [4 2 5 5], I take the first two imaginary entries from the fnt1d, and concatenate the real and imaginary coefficients to a vector.

texts.html: So I wanted to see if realnoiselet from Justin Romberg yields the same values. But if I use that function I get [12 8 6 6]. Which (as I figured out) are the sums and differences of the elements 1 and 3 respectively 2 and 4 of the vector [3.5 4.5 -0.5 1.5]. Rearranged and multiplied with 2.
text: So I wanted to see if realnoiselet from Justin Romberg yields the same values. But if I use that function I get [12 8 6 6]. Which (as I figured out) are the sums and differences of the elements 1 and 3 respectively 2 and 4 of the vector [3.5 4.5 -0.5 1.5]. Rearranged and multiplied with 2.

texts.html: Why is that? Is [12 8 6 6] the right answer? Does that mean the answer to Q1 is not right?
text: Why is that? Is [12 8 6 6] the right answer? Does that mean the answer to Q1 is not right?

texts.html: Thank you very much!
